Roger Clemens has become the 8th winningest pitcher in baseball history with his 343rd victory. Clemens beat Greg Maddux as the two best pitchers of their generation went head to head. Both will make baseball's Hall of Fame, Clemens with power, Maddux with finesse. Maddux has 325 wins. 
 
 Winningest pitchers all time 
 
 1 Cy Young 511 
 2 Walter Johnson 417 
 3 Grover Alexander 373 
 3 Christy Mathewson 373 
 5 Warren Spahn 363 
 6 Pud Galvin 361 
 7 Kid Nichols 361 
 8 Roger Clemens 343

post_info.post_title: Roger Clemens is number 8 in wins

That's weird, I haven't heard of any on the list other than the top 3.

That's weird, I haven't heard of any on the list other than the top 3.
Maybe it's your age, or even the fact that you don't give a rat's tootie about baseball. Funny that you have heard of Alexander and not Mathewson. Their careers overlapped and Mathewson may have been a bit better.
 
 Cy Young 1890-1911 (22 yrs - 511 wins) avg 23.23 wins/year (.618 w/l %)
 Walter Johnson 1907-1927 (21 yrs - 417 wins) avg 19.86 wins/year (.599 w/l %)
 Grover Alexander 1911-1930 (20 yrs - 373 wins) avg 18.65 wins/year (.642 w/l %)
 Christy Mathewson 1900-1916 (17 yrs - 373 wins) avg 21.94 wins/year (.665 w/l %)
 Warren Spahn 1942-1965 (24 yrs - 363 wins) avg 15.13 wins/year (.597 w/l %)
 Pud Galvin 1875-1892 (18 yrs - 361 wins) avg 20.06 wins/year (.540 w/l %)
 Kid Nichols 1890-1905 (14 yrs* - 361 wins) 25.79 wins/year (.634 w/l %)
 Roger Clemens 1984-2006 (23 yrs**) 14.91 wins/year (.665 w/l %)
 
 * sat out 2 seasons
 ** 2006 partial season incomplete. Through 2005 season - 15.5 wins/year
 
 Of course, such statistics are basically meaningless since the number of games played in any given season has changed. The number of wins is more indicative of a combination of things - staying power, skill, and supporting team.
 
 However, for purposes of discussion I supply the following list by W/L. These are the previous pitchers with the addition of some who I have seen pitch or who came to mind. This may not be meaningful either since Roger Clemens ranks at the top and hasn't had the hitting to support his pitching. He doesn't give up many runs, but he gets fewer in support. Feel free to add to the list.

 .665 Christy Mathewson *
 .665 Roger Clemens *
